content.value: How has countries’ climate action to meet emission targets progressed?

Effective climate action is key to achieving countries’ NDCs and net-zero targets. The IPAC Climate Actions and Policies Measurement Framework (CAPMF) monitors trends in climate mitigation policy adoption and policy stringency
Policy stringency is defined as the degree to which policies incentivise emissions reductions. Following the methodology of the OECD Environmental Policy Stringency Index
[167] Botta, E. and T. Koźluk (2014), “Measuring Environmental Policy Stringency in OECD Countries: A Composite Index Approach”
[166] Kruse, T. et al. (2022), “Measuring environmental policy stringency in OECD countries: An update of the OECD composite EPS indicator”

, the CAPMF operationalises stringency as a relative concept by assigning a stringency score between 0 (not stringent) and 10 (very stringent) for each policy variable based on the in-sample distribution across all countries and years of the policy variables’ level (e.g. tax rate, emission limit value, government expenditure). Basing policy stringency on a relative concept implies that high stringency values in a particular country do not necessarily suggest that the policy is stringent enough to meet its mitigation goals. Rather, it means that the policy in this country and year was more stringent compared to all other countries and years.
for OECD and OECD partner countries.

The CAPMF is a comprehensive harmonised policy database that measures the adoption and stringency of 56 climate actions and policies based on 128 policy variables, from 2000-2022 across 50 countries and the EU-27. The United States has been excluded from the CAPMF as the policy data has not been fully verified and validated.

The CAPMF covers a broad range of policy instruments (e.g. market-based, non-market based) and other climate actions (e.g. climate targets, climate governance, climate data), comprising  75% of instruments listed in the IPCC 6
IPCC Sixth Assessment Report Working Group III: Mitigation of Climate Change

. It covers several important sector-specific policies that are jointly responsible for 89% of GHG emissions in OECD and OECD partner countries. Although there are still data gaps (e.g. AFOLU sector, see Annex I for details), the CAPMF still allows for an extensive overview of countries’ climate action over time.
Countries’ overall national climate action slowed down in 2022

In 2022, overall national climate action, as captured by the CAPMF, slowed down in the OECD and OECD partner countries. The total number of adopted policies did not expand while the stringency of policies remained roughly constant (
). Even before 2022, climate action was not strong enough to be compatible with the temperature goal of the Paris Agreement
The Climate Action Monitor 2022: Helping Countries Advance Towards Net Zero
. In 2022 climate action only expanded 0.5%, the lowest growth ever recorded between 2000 and 2022. In contrast, between 2000 and 2021, overall climate action
Operationally, the CAPMF measures climate action as the simple average of policy stringency across all actions and policies included in the CAPMF.
increased by an average 9% a year (For more details see Annex

The slowdown in climate action can be explained by governments’ reaction to a complex mix of geopolitical and macroeconomic shocks. The energy crisis triggered countries to ramp up fossil fuel support to new record levels while postponing planned climate actions, such as carbon pricing and the phased out of fossil fuel infrastructure. With the exception of the implementation of the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) in the United States -although not considered in the CAPMF- the fiscal space of most governments to provide additional support to low-carbon technologies became increasingly limited due to increased government spending on recovery packages in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and rising interest rates to curb inflation
The OECD Green Recovery Database: Examining the environmental implications of COVID-19 recovery policies

The OECD estimated that only 17% of the recovery spending tracked between 2019 and March 2021 can be accounted as environmentally-positive – the same amount as mixed and environmentally-negative measures combined.

Some policies (e.g. minimum energy performance standards, energy labels, air emissions standards for coal power plants) have already been widely adopted, further limiting the space for new policy adoption.

Notwithstanding the general slowdown in climate policies, the energy crisis also triggered more climate action. Concerns over energy security and reliance on fossil fuels motivated some countries to adopt more ambitious targets on renewables and energy efficiency. These targets and commitments, as well as some types of policy measures (e.g. support to green investment) are not yet fully captured by the CAPMF. Further developments of the CAPMF will reveal whether countries underpin these targets by appropriate climate policies in the coming years, and if the aggregate trends on climate action improves.
The slowdown in 2022 poses a significant risk and may derail countries’ commitments. Stronger climate action, as measured by the CAPMF, points to steeper emissions reductions
[48] Nachtigall, D. et al. (2022), “The climate actions and policies measurement framework: A structured and harmonised climate policy database to monitor countries’ mitigation action”

. However, the CAPMF data shows that all countries still have multiple options to strengthen their action by increasing the stringency of existing policies or by adopting new policies that are currently not widely used (e.g. carbon pricing in the building and transport sector, bans and phase-outs of fossil fuel extraction as well as fossil fuel based heating and transportation modes).
The slowdown of overall climate action masks important cross-country differences
Some countries managed to strengthen their national climate action in 2022, but others did not. In total, 15 OECD and 4 OECD partner countries - accounting for 25% of global GHG emissions
The emissions from the European Union are excluded in this share to avoid double-counting.

- experienced a decrease of climate action in 2022. This was caused, among others, by decreases of public expenditure in research and development in low-carbon technologies such as renewables, energy efficiency or CCS (e.g. Denmark, Czech Republic, Germany). Some countries postponed the phase out date of fossil fuel infrastructure (e.g. Hungary). Others (e.g. United Kingdom) reduced the funding for their climate advisory body.

There were, however, also several positive developments in 2022. 21 OECD and 8 OECD partner countries – accounting for 38% of global GHG emissions – strengthened climate action in 2022. However, only 3 of those countries expanded climate action by more than the average increase in previous years. The increase in 2022 was driven principally by new or enhanced net-zero pledges, strengthened regulatory measures and advances in international climate policy frameworks (see below). For example, India submitted its NDC aligned to a net-zero target by 2070, Chile put its net-zero target in law and the European Union significantly enhanced its climate action with its ‘Fit for 55’ package that includes, among others, amendments to its Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) as well as regulations to strengthen energy efficiency and renewables. The United Kingdom strongly increased the auctions for solar and wind energy and tightened the ETS on industry and electricity. Finally, Austria launched its national ETS for the transport and building sector in 2022.

Climate action is increasingly diverging across countries
Climate action is increasingly diverging between OECD and OECD partner countries (

). Some OECD countries had already stronger policies in place and accelerated climate action faster than other countries. For example, European Union countries subject to EU regulation have already adopted a wide range of climate policies in the past and have continued expanding climate action at a fast pace. While the trend of divergence can be observed between 2000 and 2020, it accelerated markedly in 2021, though not in 2022.

Diverging climate action reinforces the call for more international co-ordination and co-operation on climate action, notably in times of the current geopolitical challenges. Achieving the Paris Agreement long-term temperature goal requires improved institutional, technical, and human capacity and scale up finance for climate action. Moreover, in an interconnected world diverging climate action across countries may affect competitiveness and trigger carbon leakage, therefore, limiting the effectiveness of increased climate action
[49] Nachtigall, D. et al. (2021), “The economic and environmental benefits from international co-ordination on carbon pricing: Insights from economic modelling studies”
. Some countries, notably the European Union, started to implement safeguards such as border carbon adjustment to reduce the risk of carbon leakage and mitigate negative competitiveness effects
OECD Economic Surveys: European Union and Euro Area 2023

Climate action in international climate cooperation policies and cross-sectoral policies expanded marginally, but slowed down for sectoral policies
Climate action in international climate cooperation policies

International policies are related to international climate co-operation (e.g. participation in international initiatives and agreements), international finance (e.g. participation in international emissions pricing schemes such as CORSIA) or compliance with international reporting requirements under the UNFCCC.

Cross-sectoral actions and policies refer to policies that cut across more than one emission source or sector. These are overarching policy areas to mitigate or remove domestic GHG emissions that cannot be easily attributed to a specific sector (e.g. GHG emissions targets, climate governance).
continued its upward trend in 2022, though at a significantly slower pace compared with previous years (
). The increase in international climate action and cross-sectoral action was stronger in OECD partner countries than in OECD countries (

). The increase in international climate action observed after 2020 can mostly be attributed to i) the Arrangement on Officially Supported Export Credits, in which participants agreed to end the support for unabated coal power plants
; ii) a joint commitment forged at COP26 in 2021 that committed signatories to “align international public support towards the clean energy transition and out of unabated fossil fuels”
STATEMENT ON INTERNATIONAL PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR THE CLEAN ENERGY TRANSITION
; and iii) the launch of the pilot phase of CORSIA. Climate action in cross-sectoral policies principally increased due to enhanced NDCs and net-zero targets in some countries.

Sectoral policies are defined as policies that can be constrained to or are designed to apply to a specific source or economic sector (e.g. emission limit values for passenger cars, phase out of power plants).
slowed down in 2022. The slight increase of climate action in the building sector was offset by decreases of climate action in both the electricity and the industry sector (

). This was mostly due to a decrease in governments’ activity of renewable energy auctions, postponed phase out dates of coal power plants as well as carbon tax breaks for energy-intensive industries in view of the energy crises. Climate action in the transport sector – the sector with least progress on climate action between 2010 and 2021 – halted in 2022.

The slowdown of climate action in sectoral policies is of concern, since sectoral policies are key levers to reduce sector-specific GHG emissions. In fact, most countries emphasise the importance of sectoral policies in their NDCs. For example, 92% and 83% of countries declare that action in the electricity and transport sectors respectively are key mitigation strategies to reach their NDCs, whereas only 78% report the same for cross-sectoral policies
Nationally Determined Contributions under the Paris Agreement: Synthesis Report by the Secretariat

. In addition, the slowdown of climate action takes place in the two sectors that account for the highest shares of GHG emissions in OECD and OECD partner countries with 36% (electricity) and 22% (industry) respectively (Chapter 1).

The relative importance of market-based instruments decreased in the last decade

Policy mixes are the result of complex interactions between climate action in the past, climate ambitions, emissions’ profile, available technologies as well as countries’ social, political, and institutional conditions. There is no one-size-fits all approach and each country needs to tailor its policy mix to its country-specific circumstances to best reduce GHG emissions. All types of climate actions and policies have a role to play in reducing emissions and achieving the long-term temperature goal of the Paris Agreement:

Market-based instruments (MBIs) such as subsidies and carbon pricing change relative prices to shift the investment, production and consumption decisions towards low-carbon alternatives. Carbon pricing schemes are also a source of revenues to finance climate action.

Non-market-based instruments (nMBIs) such as standards and information instruments are instrumental to mainstream advanced low-carbon technologies, provide climate-relevant information to stakeholders, steer broad, bottom-up support for climate measures, and develop the infrastructure for low-carbon alternatives.

Targets (e.g. net-zero targets and NDCs), international co-operation, governance and climate data are key enabling conditions for effective mitigation. While these actions may not have a direct material effect on emissions, they provide the policy framework with mid- and long-term signals for all stakeholders. They also create the institutional capacity to effectively implement policies, enable the tracking of progress, and identify key emissions’ drivers.
Climate action on MBIs significantly slowed down between 2010 and 2022 (

). While action on nMBIs and ‘Targets, governance and climate data’ increased by 88% and almost 300% respectively, action on MBI only increased by 43% between 2010 and 2022. The slowdown of MBIs is in line with OECD findings on carbon pricing, which show that countries are advancing carbon pricing at a slow pace
Effective Carbon Rates 2023: Pricing greenhouse gas emissions through taxes and emissions trading
Effective Carbon Rates 2021 - Pricing Carbon Emissions through Taxes and Emissions Trading
Effective Carbon Rates 2018 - Pricing Carbon Emissions Through Taxes and Emissions Trading

. Part of the slowdown can be explained by relatively moderate increases in policy adoption. While the number of adopted MBIs increased by 33% between 2010 and 2022, the number of adopted nMBIs as well as policies related to ‘Targets, governance and climate data’ increased by 66% and 250%, respectively.

These findings suggests that the relative importance of MBIs in countries’ policy mixes has decreased, despite their perceived cost-effectiveness and economic efficiency to reduce emissions. A possible explanation is the lack of public acceptability, notably for carbon pricing
[57] Jenkins, J. (2014), “Political economy constraints on carbon pricing policies: What are the implications for economic efficiency, environmental efficacy, and climate policy design?”,
[58] Dechezleprêtre, A. et al. (2022), “Fighting climate change: International attitudes toward climate policies”

. Carbon pricing design, that contemplates revenue recycling or other mechanisms to deal with public resistance, can better compensate vulnerable households and help boost public support for these approaches. Indeed, countries use different revenue recycling approaches
[59] Nachtigall, D., J. Ellis and S. Errendal (2022), “Carbon pricing and COVID-19: Policy changes, challenges and design options in OECD and G20 countries”

In 2022, progress on market-based instruments slowed down further
In 2022, overall climate action on market-based instruments further slowed down (

). This is the result of two opposing trends. While there was progress in some areas (e.g. permit prices in most ETS increased - partly driven by more stringent emissions caps set by countries), there was massive backtracking on others, notably related to fossil fuel support (see below). These opposing actions can also be observed in preliminary information reported to the OECD Policy Instruments for the Environment (PINE) database
Policy Instruments for the Environment Database

. Out of nine countries with preliminary data, four (France, Italy, Portugal, and Slovakia) saw a reduction on energy related tax revenue in 2022, and 5 countries saw an increase (Denmark, Estonia, Luxembourg, Norway, and Sweden)
Environmental policy: Environmentally related tax revenue
Countries made some progress on carbon pricing, but much more needs to be done

Progress on carbon pricing has been mixed since 2020. On the positive side, between 2020 and 2022 eight new carbon pricing instruments were adopted, mostly in form of emissions trading schemes (ETS), covering the transport and buildings sectors. For example, Austria and Germany introduced a national ETS for transportation and buildings, which are not yet covered by the EU ETS. The EU proposed, under its ‘Fit for 55’ package, a separate ETS to cover transport and heating fuels in the bloc from 2026 and to further expand the sectoral coverage of its existing ETS to maritime transport. In terms of price levels, ETS permit prices reached new highs, increasing from an average of EUR 11.2 per tCO
Effective Carbon Rates 2023: Pricing greenhouse gas emissions through taxes and emissions trading

On the negative side, some countries responded to the energy crisis by controlling prices or (temporarily) removing or reducing taxes on energy. This price support weighs on government budgets and distorts price signals. For example, Germany temporarily froze the scheduled price increases of its national ETS
, OECD Environmental Performance Reviews, OECD Publishing, Paris, https://doi.org/
Despite this progress, more needs to be done. While many countries have a high share of economy‑wide GHG emissions subject to a positive net effective carbon rate
Net Effective Carbon Rate (NECR) is the sum of fuel excise taxes, carbon taxes and tradeable permits, that effectively put a price on carbon emissions, adjusted by fossil fuel support.

(e.g. Iceland, Korea, Luxemburg), price levels are too low to be compatible with Paris Agreement temperature goal. In fact, only three countries (Switzerland, Luxemburg, Norway) price more than 50% of its GHG emissions at more than EUR 60 (
) - a medium range estimate deemed to be necessary to reach climate goals
Report of the High-Level Commission on Carbon Prices
. In most countries, notably in large economies, this share is around or below 25%. In addition, GHGs such as CH
O, and F-gases remain largely unpriced.

Fossil fuel subsidies rose to a new record in 2022
Fossil fuel consumption subsidies increased dramatically, rising to a new record in 2022 by surpassing for the first time USD 1 trillion

. Fossil fuel subsidies send the wrong price signal to energy consumers and need to be limited and restricted to meet the long-term temperature goal of the Paris Agreement. Most of the rise in subsidies was related to the energy crisis, as governments shielded vulnerable consumers and firms from energy price hikes. Once energy prices normalise, it is expected that fossil fuel subsidies will decrease. By contrast, global subsidies on clean energy technologies were about 600 billion annually for the same period

content.value: Support for RD&D for clean energy increased, driven by China
Despite recent economic uncertainties, global public spending on energy research development and demonstration (RD&D) increased by 5%, up to USD 44 billion in 2022 compared to 2021 (

). The share of clean energy RD&D rose from 79% in 2020 to 80% and 81% in 2021 and 2022. Virtually all the growth of public RD&D investment in 2022 was driven by China, which boosted its spending in its 14

Five-Year Plan for the period 2021-2025, making it the country with the largest energy RD&D public spending. Public spending slightly decreased in Europe, North America, and the rest of the world in 2022. Yet, spending is expected to rebound for North America with the US Inflation Reduction Act, which is the largest single boost in clean energy innovation funding at the national level that directly funds RD&D and supports the scale-up of near-commercial technologies.

Climate action of non-market-based instruments marginally increased in 2022
Countries marginally increased the adoption and stringency of non-market-based instruments in 2022 (see

above). However, there is still plenty of scope for them to adopt new measures or strengthen existing ones. Information instruments (e.g. labels for appliances and fuel efficiency for passenger cars) and some regulatory instruments such as minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) for appliances, air pollution standards for coal-power plants, and fuel efficiency standards for passenger cars have been implemented since the 1990s. Other standards (e.g. building energy codes and MEPS for electric motors) are more recent, but not all OECD and OECD partner countries have implemented these standards in 2022.

While performance standards have been adopted in most countries between the 1990s and the 2010s, their stringency can be further increased to support the uptake of more advanced low-carbon technologies. For example, the European Union plans to increase, in 2023, the required efficiency level of electric motors to International Efficiency level IV –the most stringent level that any country has put in place.
Bans and phase outs of fossil fuel assets and equipment are increasingly used to shift consumption and production decisions
Bans and phase outs of fossil fuel assets and equipment have become an increasingly popular tool in countries (

). These technology standards help mainstream low-carbon technologies by prohibiting the sale of conventional technologies based on fossil fuels (a ban) or prohibiting the use of the respective fossil-based technology altogether (a phase out). Phase outs also send a clear signal from on governments’ commitment for all stakeholders in the energy transition, enabling stakeholders to plan accordingly. The total number of bans and phase outs across all technologies covered in the CAMPF (e.g. coal power plants, fossil fuel heating) increased from 12 in 2015 to 135 in 2022.

However, some countries backtracked from previous commitments in 2022. For example, formerly coal‑free Austria placed one coal plant in the reserve in view of the energy crisis whereas Hungary postponed the phase out date of its lignite power plant from 2025 to 2030. More recently, the European Union adjusted the planned ban of the sale of diesel and petrol passenger cars from 2035, by allowing the sale of cars that run on carbon-neutral synthetic fuels. These fuels are expected to play a key role in the decarbonisation of hard-to-abate sectors such as aviation, although they are not yet produced at scale. Allowing the use of synthetic fuels for passenger cars where low-carbon alternatives in form of electric vehicles exist, could divert the use of these fuels from hard-to-abate sectors, hampering mitigation efforts in those sectors
[68] Ueckerdt, F. et al. (2021), “Potential and risks of hydrogen-based e-fuels in climate change mitigation”,

After much momentum with the launch of the Beyond Oil and Gas Alliance (BOGA) at COP26 in 2021 by seven countries (e.g. Costa Rica), no additional country announced to ban the exploration of fossil fuels within their territory in 2022

. Conversely, many countries accelerated fossil fuel extraction or the construction of fossil fuel infrastructure such as liquified natural gas (LNG) terminals for energy security reasons. For example, to reduce its dependency on Russian gas supply, Germany built two new public LNG terminals within less than one year
, OECD Environmental Performance Reviews, OECD Publishing, Paris, https://doi.org/

. In August 2023, the UK unfolded a plan approving the drilling of untapped fossil fuel reserves in the North Sea. Worryingly, almost 50% of fossil fuel producing countries state their intention to maintain or even increase fossil fuel production in their latest NDCs
(International Institute for Sustainable Development et al., 2023[70])
[70] International Institute for Sustainable Development et al. (2023),
Connecting the dots: mapping references to fossil fuel production in national plans under the UNFCCC for the 2023 Global Stocktake

The increasing availability of low-cost renewable technologies such as solar photovoltaics (PV) and wind power has supported progress in banning or phasing out coal-power. Lower renewable cost implies that reducing coal’s share in the electricity mix has become both feasible and economically viable (Chapter 4). In fact, solar PV saw a massive increase in adoption in the last years, rendering it one of the few clean energy technologies whose adoption is in line with limiting global warming to 1.5°C
Net Zero Roadmap: A Global Pathway to Keep the 1.5 °C Goal in Reach

. Phase out dates vary across countries, ranging from 2023 (e.g. Slovakia) to 2030 (e.g. Mexico) to 2056 (e.g. Indonesia). In a welcome move, India – the country with the second largest coal plant fleet after China – announced a ban on the construction of new coal power plants beyond those that are already under construction.
Countries should further strengthen climate governance and climate data
Adoption of targets, governance, international co-ordination and climate data, varies widely across climate actions (

). All OECD and OECD partner countries submitted their NDCs and most of them have net-zero targets in place. All these countries are signatories to the Paris Agreement and most other key international climate treaties.

Apart from the Paris Agreement, other climate treaties tracked by the CAPMF include: the Montreal Protocol, the Montreal Amendment, the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol, the UNFCCC framework convention.
Similarly, all these countries are part of at least, two international initiatives (e.g. Malta, Saudi Arabia) and some up to 38 (e.g. United Kingdom).
[48] Nachtigall, D. et al. (2022), “The climate actions and policies measurement framework: A structured and harmonised climate policy database to monitor countries’ mitigation action”
for a list of international initiatives tracked by the CAPMF.

All countries also provide information to the UNFCCC in the form of official documents (e.g. National Communications). However, not all countries provide all mandatory or recommended information, or in a timely manner. In terms of recommended information, for example, 13 countries covered by the CAPMF have not yet submitted their long-term low emissions development strategy (LT-LEDS). A LT-LEDS is a key document providing guidance to stakeholders on national plans to reach long-term targets
[72] Aguilar Jaber, A. et al. (2020), “Long-term low emissions development strategies: Cross-country experience”

Climate advisory bodies play a role in supporting climate action through stakeholder involvement and providing key scientific information. As of 2022, only 13 countries had established independent climate advisory bodies of which 12 are created by law. In 2021 or 2022 some countries stepped up their funding of climate advisory bodies including Australia, Canada and Denmark. Switzerland, on the other hand, abolished its advisory body in 2021, though it plans to reinstate a similar entity while mainstreaming the institutions to provide climate advice.
Despite the call for countries to ramp up ambition and submit updated (second) NDCs in advance of COP27, only 8 countries updated their NDCs in advance of COP27 including Brazil and Korea.
Other countries that updated their NDCs in advance of COP28 include Australia, Indonesia, Mexico, Norway, Switzerland and the United Kingdom.
While most countries submitted their second NDCs in 2020 or 2021, India submitted its second NDC in 2022.
Climate action and the policy landscape

Monitoring trends in climate action is essential to assess countries’ climate effort. The Climate Action and Policies Measurement Framework, the basis for the analysis presented in this chapter, provides data on the adoption and stringency of selected relevant climate mitigation actions and policies.

However, the effectiveness of policies, as well as the choices available to policymakers, must be viewed in the context of the broader policy landscape. Some events, conditions, or trends can act as “tailwinds” supporting and facilitating the transition to net-zero, such technological progress, renewable energy prices, or the discovery of critical materials. Others can restrict climate action policy effectiveness by acting as “headwinds” as they hamper the transition or reduce the range of feasible action against climate change, for example falling fossil fuel prices or international conflict.

Without identifying and understanding the full impact of these trends and events, it is difficult to assess the final impact of climate policy on mitigation outcomes. For example, Russia’s war of aggression against Ukraine was a key event in 2022. It reshuffled the climate policy landscape by disrupting global energy markets. On the one hand, it reduced access to fuels and increased energy insecurity, motivating governments to increase the development of domestic fossil fuel energy resources and supports for fuel consumption. On the other hand, high-energy prices, and concerns over long term fossil fuel supply, triggered increased funding for renewable energy sources and energy efficiency actions. The final impacts are yet to be determined.

As IPAC expands and matures, indicators that examine the broader policy landscape, as well as indicators on barriers and opportunities, and above all, on a just transition, could be developed to support decision makers policy choices. Furthermore, the OECD is embarked on a major initiative, the Inclusive Forum on Carbon Mitigation Approaches (IFCMA), to both carry out a detailed stocktake of current policy instruments as well as assess their effectiveness. This initiative, as well as complementary indicators, are essential to get a complete picture of countries’ mitigation effort and will be the cornerstone of OECD work on climate mitigation.
Policy stringency is defined as the degree to which policies incentivise emissions reductions. Following the methodology of the OECD Environmental Policy Stringency Index
[167] Botta, E. and T. Koźluk (2014), “Measuring Environmental Policy Stringency in OECD Countries: A Composite Index Approach”
[166] Kruse, T. et al. (2022), “Measuring environmental policy stringency in OECD countries: An update of the OECD composite EPS indicator”

, the CAPMF operationalises stringency as a relative concept by assigning a stringency score between 0 (not stringent) and 10 (very stringent) for each policy variable based on the in-sample distribution across all countries and years of the policy variables’ level (e.g. tax rate, emission limit value, government expenditure). Basing policy stringency on a relative concept implies that high stringency values in a particular country do not necessarily suggest that the policy is stringent enough to meet its mitigation goals. Rather, it means that the policy in this country and year was more stringent compared to all other countries and years.

The CAPMF is a comprehensive harmonised policy database that measures the adoption and stringency of 56 climate actions and policies based on 128 policy variables, from 2000-2022 across 50 countries and the EU-27. The United States has been excluded from the CAPMF as the policy data has not been fully verified and validated.
Operationally, the CAPMF measures climate action as the simple average of policy stringency across all actions and policies included in the CAPMF.

The OECD estimated that only 17% of the recovery spending tracked between 2019 and March 2021 can be accounted as environmentally-positive – the same amount as mixed and environmentally-negative measures combined.
The emissions from the European Union are excluded in this share to avoid double-counting.

International policies are related to international climate co-operation (e.g. participation in international initiatives and agreements), international finance (e.g. participation in international emissions pricing schemes such as CORSIA) or compliance with international reporting requirements under the UNFCCC.

Cross-sectoral actions and policies refer to policies that cut across more than one emission source or sector. These are overarching policy areas to mitigate or remove domestic GHG emissions that cannot be easily attributed to a specific sector (e.g. GHG emissions targets, climate governance).

Sectoral policies are defined as policies that can be constrained to or are designed to apply to a specific source or economic sector (e.g. emission limit values for passenger cars, phase out of power plants).
Net Effective Carbon Rate (NECR) is the sum of fuel excise taxes, carbon taxes and tradeable permits, that effectively put a price on carbon emissions, adjusted by fossil fuel support.

Apart from the Paris Agreement, other climate treaties tracked by the CAPMF include: the Montreal Protocol, the Montreal Amendment, the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol, the UNFCCC framework convention.

for a list of international initiatives tracked by the CAPMF.
Other countries that updated their NDCs in advance of COP28 include Australia, Indonesia, Mexico, Norway, Switzerland and the United Kingdom.
